thread.title: Saturday Night Live’s Kellyanne Conway sketch went too far for some
thread.title_full: Saturday Night Live’s Kellyanne Conway sketch went too far for some | Toronto Star

author: Brennan Doherty
title: Saturday Night Live’s Kellyanne Conway sketch went too far for some
text:
A dark sketch on Saturday Night Live this week where cast member Kate McKinnon playing Trump aide Kellyanne Conway stalks CNN host Jake Tapper is igniting controversy online. The sketch, a remake of the 1987 thriller movie Fatal Attraction, plays on CNN’s recent decision to not let the real-life Conway on air after she repeatedly referenced a non-existent massacre. In it, Tapper – played by Beck Bennett – comes home to find McKinnon-as-Conway has broken into his apartment wearing just a negligee.
“I just want to be part of the news, Jake,” McKinnon-as-Conway pleads, later pulling out a knife.
Tapper himself seemed to feel uncomfortable about the whole thing:
  Their defence? “I guess, knowing the Constitution?”
Baldwin, as Trump, refuses to tell the truth in court (“I’m good”), insists he signed a “tremendous” travel ban (“I didn’t read it, but I signed it”) and calls Russian President Vladimir Putin as a shirtless character witness. (“This man is my great friend. He’s my little American Happy Meal,” says Putin, also played by Beck Bennett).
Viewers loved it:
But the cold open on Saturday went to Melissa McCarthy who did an encore round as White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer. “First of all, I just want to announce that I’m calm now,” McCarthy begins. “This is the new ‘Spicy.’”
Seconds later, “Old Spicy” is screaming their head off yet again. When the “dumb babies” (i.e. reporters) ask about “extreme vetting” of immigrants, Spicer once again whips out the “dollies” to explain how it all works (“We know she’s OK because she’s blond!”)
McCarthy’s impression of Spicer has been on the air under two weeks, yet she’s caught much of the attention online from SNL fans and reviewers.
With files from The Associated Press 
But the cold open on Saturday went to Melissa McCarthy who did an encore round as White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer. “First of all, I just want to announce that I’m calm now,” McCarthy begins. “This is the new ‘Spicy.’”
Seconds later, “Old Spicy” is screaming their head off yet again. When the “dumb babies” (i.e. reporters) ask about “extreme vetting” of immigrants, Spicer once again whips out the “dollies” to explain how it all works (“We know she’s OK because she’s blond!”)
McCarthy’s impression of Spicer has been on the air under two weeks, yet she’s caught much of the attention online from SNL fans and reviewers.

With files from The Associated Press 
While some loved the sketch, others said it was sexist and not funny. Others worried the White House would use it as an excuse to dismiss legitimate criticisms of Conway, who was recently rebuked for endorsing Ivanka Trump’s clothing line on air — a violation of ethics rules.
